docs.lead_paragraph: With her weight dwindling to 95 pounds on her 5-foot-10-inch frame, Kathryn Bromfield decided she needed more than another trip to a hospital psychiatric ward to survive anorexia. Her insurance company, however, would not pay for residential treatment at a center specializing in eating disorders. Ms. Bromfield turned to her parents, who mortgaged their house and used credit cards to pay more than $53,000 for 11 weeks of treatment.

headline.main: Insurers Pushed to Cover Eating Disorders

docs.abstract: Advocates for victims of eating disorders hope lawsuit settled recently in Minnesota will compel insurers across country to pay for treatment for anorexia sufferers; in Minnesota case, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Minnesota has agreed to $1 million settlement with family of young woman who committed suicide after suffering from anorexia for five years and being denied coverage by Blue Cross (M)

keywords.value: BLUE CROSS & BLUE SHIELD OF MINNESOTA

docs.lead_paragraph: Raquel and Tony Rivas had their life in order. They had married, built a house and were ready to start having children. But a visit to the gynecologist led to frightening news: Ms. Rivas had cervical cancer. Although detected early, the cancer had burrowed deep enough into the tissue that it could no longer be handled superficially with freezing or lasers. To treat the malignancy and halt its spread, the couple was told, doctors would have to perform a radical hysterectomy, removing Ms. Rivas's cervix and uterus. With luck, the surgery alone would take care of the malignancy; if not, radiation or chemotherapy might also be called for. However, the operation would destroy her ability to bear children.

headline.main: Preserving Fertility While Treating Cervical Cancer

docs.abstract: New form of surgery to treat cervical cancer preserves fertility; so-called radical trachelectomy involves removal of cancerous cervical tissue using retractors inserted through vaginal canal; surgery is successful only if cancer has not spread to lymph nodes, in which case hysterectomy is needed; Raquel Rivas, who had radical trachelectomy, delivered twin girls several years later; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rock Brynner, 54, historian, writer, former road manager for The Band and for Bob Dylan and son of the late actor Yul Brynner, knows both sides of the story of the drug thalidomide. Taken by to pregnant women in Europe and Canada for morning sickness and as a sedative during the 1950's and 60's, thalidomide caused thousands of birth defects. But in recent years, doctors have begun finding important new uses for the drug.

headline.main: A 'Dark Remedy' Is Now Generating Light

docs.abstract: Interview with Rock Brynner, co-author of book, Dark Remedy, about history of thalidomide; Brynner, who suffers from rare immune disorder, has gone into remission since taking thalidomide; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The world can be a scary enough place without tales of deodorants that cause cancer, asbestos-laden tampons and, perhaps most alarming of all, the dreaded arachnius gluteus, a spider said to lurk beneath toilet seats waiting to bite those who sit. Phony though the stories may be, officials at government and private health organizations say they are increasingly having to field inquiries from people taken in by the latest medical hoax or rumor.

headline.main: Toilet Spiders? Not Real, but Good for a Scare

docs.abstract: Officials at government and private health organizations report having to field many inquiries from people taken in by latest medical hoax or rumor, such as presence of spiders lurking beneath toilet seats; in response, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other organizations have created special sections on their Web sites devoted to debunking medical myths (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A colleague who's an oncologist called to say he had referred a patient to me. I thanked him and didn't think much about it until I was seated opposite the patient, an elderly man, beginning the consultation. In a standard psychiatric evaluation, the first section is called, rather unsympathetically, the Chief Complaint or C.C. It is usually the patient's statement of the problem that caused him or her to seek out a psychiatrist: ''My wife and I are having difficulties'' or '' I feel anxious all the time at work'' or ''I think I'm depressed.''

headline.main: An Escort Into the Land Of Sickness

docs.abstract: Cases column by Dr Anna Fels, psychiatrist, recounts sessions with patient who was having problems with fact that he was dying; says man spoke not about death but about its seamier, squalid, physical side and unwanted psychological deformations that illness brings with it; says isolation imposed by impersonal, alien world of illness had become almost as debilitating as illness itself; says man just needed to talk and did not want to burden his family (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cervical cancer was once the leading cancer killer of American women. Now, thanks largely to the widespread use of an early detection exam, it is the seventh. The death rate is less than one-tenth what it was 50 years ago. But the sharp decline in cases and deaths here and in other industrialized countries in the last half century has led to complacency that may reverse this downward trend. This year about 12,900 women in the United States will be told they have cervical cancer and another 4,400 will die of the disease. Worldwide, the situation is far worse, with half a million new cases occurring annually. In some developing countries, cervical cancer remains the leading cancer killer of women.

headline.main: Regular Pap Tests Remain a Crucial Detection Method

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on importance of annual Pap test to detect cervical cancer; says more than half cervical cancer cases in United States involve women who have not had Pap tests in previous three years; drawing (M)
